intro: Diacalpe foeniculacea, commonly known as the golden sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in sandy soils and is adapted to drought conditions, making it a hardy plant in desert environments. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies in arid ecosystems.
